awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Chuanbing Tang of the University of South Carolina and Professor Stephen L. Craig of Duke University to develop a new class of polymers (plastics) that respond to specific types of stress. Synthetic polymers are versatile, processable, light weight, and have tunable mechanical properties, making them useful in everyday life. These metal-containing polymers made by the Tang group are used to make polymer materials that respond to physical pressures but are stable at high temperatures.  The team's research explores the design and potential uses of mechanochemically-controlled plastics. Such plastics may be recycled by physical manipulation rather than re-melting, ultimately resulting in energy-savings during reuse.  Outreach activities include the Chem-STAR program that provides research resources to primarily undergraduate institutions in the Raleigh-Durham area.  Economically disadvantaged and minority students are also mentored and exposed to cutting-edge research through American Chemical Society Project SEED summer research program at the University of South Carolina. 
 
This project is focused on developing synthetic approaches toward main-chain metallocene-containing polymers and studying their mechanochemical reactivity.  The research plan utilizes ring-opening metathesis polymerization to synthesize well-defined main-chain metallocene polymers and copolymers.  Experimental characterization of metallocene mechanochemistry is carried out through a combination of state-of-the-art techniques in polymer sonochemistry and single molecule force spectroscopy.  Metallocene lability in polymers is further investigated using computational models that simulate forces applied at the molecular level.  Mechanistic studies are conducted in order to elucidate the relative contribution of peeling versus shearing at the molecular scale.  The overarching goal of this work is to understand the mechanisms and structure-activity relationship underlying the highly selective mechanochemical scission of metal-cyclopentadienyl bond. This work has the potential to develop synthetic polymers that are mechanically responsive and thermally stable, both of which are important for reusability and recyclability of most commodity polymers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits

We have uncovered mechanochemical reactivity of metallocenes, including ferrocene, ruthenocene, and cobaltocenium and establish the structure-reactivity relationship. Even though the metal-Cp coordination bond is thermodynamically stable, like C-C bond, it is mechanochemically labile, like C-N bond in azobisisobutyronitrile. The University of South Carolina and Duke University have worked together to design monomer and polymer systems containing these metallocene mechanophores. The collaboration between the two groups combines the expertise in metallocene polymer chemistry at USC and that of polymer mechanochemistry at Duke. Together we have achieved the following objectives of this project: (1) we prepared cyclic metallocene and metallocenophane monomers ring-closing metathesis (RCM) and successfully synthesis main-chain metallocene-containing polymers via ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP). (2) We combined pulsed sonication and single molecule force spectroscopy methods to explore the mechanochemistry of main-chain metallocene polymers. We demonstrated that neutral ferrocene and ruthenocene and cationic cobaltocenium are active mechanophores and assessed the relative mechanochemical reactivity of these metallocenes. (3)  Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations have been employed as a very useful tool to probe the evolution of molecular and electronic structure in metallocenes under external force and corroborate with experimental observations. (4) most importantly, we have found that these metallocene compounds have very unique mechanistic scissions, including peeling vs. shearing mechanisms. We designed quantitative mechanochemical methodology to trap reactive intermediates and mechanochemical scission products, explore the possible influence of added reactants, and use conformationally restricted metallocenophanes to probe mechanically coupled reaction pathways.

Broader Impacts

Understanding the origins of the remarkable reactivity of metallocenes and how to exploit it carries transformative potential for the fields of mechanochemistry, organometallics, and polymer chemistry. During the lifetime of this project, we have jointly disseminated our scientific discoveries to the broad communities and published the research findings in high impact journals such as Nature Chemistry, Journal of American Chemical Society, and Macromolecules.

This award has nurtured professional scientists and future leaders. Two graduate students funded directly by this award have obtained doctoral degrees. A few other graduate students who were partially supported either finished are actively pursuing their PhDs. Among them three are females and one Hispanic. We have supervised at least three undergraduate students from USC and one high school student at Duke. We continued the signature project seed program at USC to allow high school students from economically disadvantaged families to spend summer in our laboratories. 

 


Last Modified: 12/03/2023
Modified by: Stephen L Craig
